newsitem.title: USA: Republican Congress mixes success and scandals.
newsitem.headline: Republican Congress mixes success and scandals.

text.p: Admire it, revile it but most of all remember the first Republican Congress in 40 years for legislative landmarks, deep political division and government shutdowns.
As the 104th Congress fades into history, these may be the top dozen memories that will linger:

-- Americans, who always said they wanted less government, did not like it when they got it. Republicans orchestrated two government shutdowns that failed to produce a budget deal with President Clinton -- but did provoke public ire as "closed" signs went up at government offices and national parks.

-- Bob Dole surprised the country with an emotional decision to end a 36-year congressional career after he found he was unable to juggle his presidential campaign and Senate leadership amid guerrilla warfare by Democrats.

-- House Speaker Newt Gingrich showed extraordinary domination of the national political debate and mastery of the House Republican majority, but also struggled with ethical problems including a $4.5 million book deal and his demonisation by Democrats and the Clinton administration.

-- A year-long investigation of the Whitewater affair dogging President and Mrs. Clinton raised serious questions about the Clintons' conduct in 60 days of highly partisan hearings chaired by Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-New York.
-- A public perception that the United States was being overrun by immigrants, legal and illegal, led to legislation that sought to restrict both but wound up dealing mostly with illegal immigration.

-- Calling the war on poverty a failure, Republicans pushed through a historic bill ending a 61-year guarantee of federal aid to poor children, limiting benefits to five years and giving states new power to design their own welfare programmes.

-- Remember the health care crisis? Congress did, passing laws to help Americans keep insurance if they changed jobs or were ill. In a election-year nod to motherhood, lawmakers made insurers provide 48-hour hospital coverage for new moms.

-- Democrats posted a come-from-behind victory when Congress passed a bill raising the minimum wage from $4.25 to $5.15 an hour, something they did not do in the previous two years when they controlled Congress and the White House.

-- The graphic language of street debates came inside the Capitol as Congress passed, and Clinton vetoed, a bill to ban some late-term abortions. Congress voted more than 50 times on measures to restrict abortion.
-- Lawmakers sped onto the information superhighway, deregulating the telecommunications industry and paving the way for new technologies.
-- Farmers will have to produce for the market instead of the government under a landmark act phasing out Depression-era subsidies and planting restrictions.
-- Republicans tried to cut spending for toxic waste clean-up, sewage treatment and clean water only to face a rebellion in their ranks and attacks from Democrats.
